topics.body:
"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54c19864636872678a7c0700#post_54c19864636872678a7c0700
Getting past all the trickle down/trickle up bullshit personally I'm for it, even though I have 20k in debts, because more disposable income means more consumer spending.

I also fucking called it that this was going to eventually happen.  Getting a bit philosophical here but in the end almost every ideal is transient; what I mean by this is that for the past hundred years economics has operated under the principle that nothing will ever happen to change the variables when it comes to economies.  What do I mean by this?  Easy: "What do you think would happen if OPEC were to not reduce production?" "It will never happen" "If it would happen what would you think would happen?"  "It doesn't matter cause it will never happen".  Or in the current context "What do you think would happen if the USA started experiencing deflation in spite of governmental spending"  "It will never happen" "Okay; well hypothetically if it were to happen what do you think the fallout of it would be" "There's no point in arguing cause the probability of it happening are small and therefore it will never happen".

To put it simply people tend to think that cause something has say a 60% chance of happening that therefore it has a 100% chance of happening; on the flip side people tend to think that cause something has say a 1% chance of happening that therefore it has a 0% chance of happening.


Which brings us back to gas prices, deflation and the upcoming deflation crisis.

What do I mean by this?  Easy; the usa is not governmentally prepared for deflation.  The usa plan of how to tackle the deficit was to continue to continue inflation until the real cost of the deficit could be easily paid off; that's why both parties have constantly refused to have a balanced budget because no inflation equals the real world cost of that deficit not decreasing.

I have to disagree with a lot of people on the deflation being temporary; personally I think it'll be extremely long term because the price of oil is going down, there's multiple new technologies coming out soon that will decrease our consumption of oil thus leading to more deflation, there's multiple new technologies coming out soon that will decrease cost of manufacturing and so forth.


Tl:dr; personally I think the deflation is going to be long term deflation and that it's not going away any time soon at all.

*Short version:
USA government, "FUCK!  We're going to have to pay back our deficit in full"
Consumers, "WOOHOO!"*

There's actually an explanation for that. Because Yoko spent most of her life underground, her concept of tine is much different from ours. She didn't count her birthday by the passing of the sun and moon. She's actually eighteen.
